### Overview

**Motivation**

-   ***Personally***: renewable energy sector; environmental science; interest in climate policy
-   ***A Climate Plan for Austria***: specific focus on Austria for the project
-   ***Testing methodology***: application of methodology to sectors other than road transport emissions

**Methodology**

-   Replication of Koch et al. (2022)
-   Reverse causal approach using GETS, for all Austrian sectors
-   Samples: EU15 and EU31
-   Target significance levels: 5%, 1% and 0.1%

**Data**

-   IEA-EDGAR CO2 emissions database (v7.0)
-   1996-2021
-   Updated from EDGAR v5.0 from the original paper (1996-2018)

### Overview

**Emissions breakdown in Austria**

```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Emissions by sector in Austria", fig.height = 4.5, fig.width = 10}
emissions_codes <- read.csv("Data/01 Source_data/IPCC 2006 Categories.csv") %>%
  select(IPCC, IPCC_description) %>% 
  mutate(IPCC_description = str_replace(IPCC_description, "Main Activity Electricity and Heat Production", "Electricity and Heat Production"),
         IPCC_description = str_replace(IPCC_description, "Petroleum Refining - Manufacture of Solid Fuels and Other Energy Industries", "Petroleum Refining"),
         IPCC_description = str_replace(IPCC_description, "Non-Energy Products from Fuels and Solvent Use", "Non-Energy Fuels"),
         IPCC_description = str_replace(IPCC_description, "Incineration and Open Burning of Waste", "Incineration of Waste"),
         IPCC_description = str_replace(IPCC_description, "Manufacturing Industries and Construction", "Manufacturing and Construction"),
         IPCC_description = str_replace(IPCC_description, "Road Transportation no resuspension", "Road Transportation"))

data <- read.csv("Data/02 Intermediary_data/CO2DriversEU_dataset_2022.csv") %>% 
    filter(country == "Austria",
           year >= 1995) %>% 
  group_by(category) %>% 
  summarise(total_emissions = sum(emissions)) %>% 
  left_join(emissions_codes, by = c("category" = "IPCC")) %>% 
  arrange(total_emissions)

data %>% 
    mutate(IPCC_description=factor(IPCC_description, IPCC_description)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=IPCC_description, y=total_emissions)) +
    geom_segment(aes(x=IPCC_description ,xend=IPCC_description, y=0, yend=total_emissions), color="grey") +
    geom_point(size=3, color="#69b3a2") +
    coord_flip() +
    theme_bw() +
    theme(
      panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
      panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
      legend.position="none") +
    xlab("IPCC emissions category") +
  ylab("Total emissions (kilotonnes carbon dioxide)")

```

### Challenges and Future Opportunities

**Challenges**

-   Calculating confidence intervals (currently reviewing Hendry and Pretis, 2023)
-   Slightly different results using EDGAR v5.0 compared to EDGAR v7.0 combined database
-   Approach to identifying EU-wide policies
-   Causal interpretation

**Future Work**

-   ***Role models***: look for most effective policies across Europe and highlight role model countries and policies. Focus on largest sectors
-   ***Upward breaks***: investigate the causes of upward breaks
-   ***Demand vs. supply***: Investigate the effectiveness of demand- vs. supply-side policies across Europe

**Questions**

-   Why a focus on road emissions? (More straightforward policy attribution? Relative volume of emissions?)
